speakerInfo.name: Wendy Wise
speakerInfo.bio: Author, Wife, Beer and Coffee Lover

schedule.title: iOS Coordinators in Practice
schedule.description: Coordinators have emerged as a popular pattern for controlling high-level application flow in iOS apps. With this pattern, you can create and sequence complex application UI flows with minimal refactoring pain. In this session, you'll see a detailed example of how they are used in a real-world application to create flexible, testable, and maintainable control flow.
schedule.speaker: Brian Hardy

speakerInfo.name: Brian Hardy
speakerInfo.bio: A passionate software craftsman, Brian loves to build great mobile apps  to help people get things done. He started working with iOS when it was still called "iPhone OS," and co-authored "Android Programming: The Big Nerd Ranch Guide."

schedule.title: Type Erasure in Swift
schedule.description:
Much has been told about type erasure, however it is still a matter of great distress for most developers!
I would like to present an example of how type erasure can be applied to solve an everyday issue!
schedule.speaker: Gonçalo Alvarez

speakerInfo.name: Gonçalo Alvarez
speakerInfo.bio: I am an experienced software engineer specialized in iOS development currently working at Farfetch. I am looking for a new challenge, to strengthen my skills and to expand my areas of expertise. Also, I am passionate about music.

schedule.title: What the Swiftly Func?
schedule.description: Functional programming is all the rage, but what is it exactly. Without resorting to confusing terms like 'Monad' and 'Functor', this talk seeks to shed a little light on this Important yet confusing approach to programming.
schedule.speaker: James Majors

speakerInfo.name: James Majors
speakerInfo.bio: iOS developer at POSSIBLE Mobile.

schedule.title: Web Accessibility
schedule.description: Web Accessibility is for everyone – it means making Websites flexible enough to meet a broad range of preferences, needs and situations. This includes not only individuals with visual, auditory or physical disabilities but anyone with limited Internet connectivity, temporary disabilities (e.g. a broken arm), or changing abilities due to aging.
schedule.speaker: Will Jayroe

speakerInfo.name: Will Jayroe
speakerInfo.bio: Will Jayroe is a multi-disciplinary professional specializing in Solutions Architecture, User Interface and Front-End Technology consulting, User Experience strategy, Visual and Interaction Design.

schedule.title: Enterprise Innovation for UX, UI, and IxD
schedule.description: Virtual reality and augmented reality present significant business opportunities for utility, information, and education. Join us for a talk about the key UX, UI, and IxD considerations that are inherent to designing for immersive content.
schedule.speaker: Dan Cotting

schedule.title: Material Design that Delights
schedule.description: By reputation, programmers aren’t great designers. “Designed by developers” usually implies a terrible user experience. Material Design is helping to change this. Google’s UX designers have developed and refined the principles behind Material Design through testing with billions of users. Using Material Design, you can create intuitive experiences with smooth animations that delight users and showcase your brand. We’ll explain Material Design principles and show you how to implement them.
schedule.speaker: Pearl Latteier,Abraham Williams

speakerInfo.name: Pearl Latteier
speakerInfo.bio: Pearl Latteier is a software engineer at Bendyworks in Madison WI. She builds JavaScript applications for web and mobile, and she has spoken at conferences around the world on topics including Progressive Web Apps, Web Components, and Polymer. Before becoming a software developer, Pearl earned a PhD in from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, where for five years she taught courses in the Department of Communication Arts.

speakerInfo.name: Abraham Williams
speakerInfo.bio: An experienced developer, start-up founder, and international speaker, Abraham Williams brings a broad range of skills to his current role as a senior developer at Bendyworks. A top 1% contributor at Stack Overflow and an active member of Google Developer Groups, Abraham has been recognized by Google as a Developer Expert for his ability to identify technology problems and provide quality solutions in the community.

schedule.title: Design & Interactivity Without Sacrificing Speed
schedule.description: Web design shouldn’t be hindered by the need for a fast, smooth loading site. However, all too often web designers find themselves choosing between creative design choices and prioritizing speed. The AMP (Accelerated Mobile Pages) Project has worked with agencies like MetaLab, North Kingdom, and Grain & Mortar to fix this by creating well-designed AMP pages that take full advantage of AMP's interactive capabilities. Now anyone can access these AMP page templates from AMPstart.com, a library of components and pages all available to download and use across the web. Not only are these pages engaging, they take full advantage of AMP's components- all ready to be used on your own site. Join Abby Beck, UX designer from Google to learn more about how you can keep design at the forefront of any web project without sacrificing speed.
schedule.speaker: Abby Beck

speakerInfo.name: Abby Beck
speakerInfo.bio: Abby Beck a Senior Product Designer at Google for the Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) team. She is a classically trained designer from the School of Visual Arts and has worked in the publishing industry in NYC, retail merchandising, and for Bay Area software companies large (Twitter, Pivotal Labs) and small. She has worked on a wide range of problems for a wide range of users (social networks, marketing products, dev tools, and hardware usage with guides). She also taught a UX Immersive course at General Assembly.  While she loves everything about design, her passion lies in systems and simplifying complex user needs.

schedule.title: UX Your Life
schedule.description: The defining characteristic of UX design is it's focus on the user and on an iterative, user-centered, approach to creating solutions. But what if we applied the user-centered design process to ourselves, our lives, and our careers.
schedule.speaker: JD Jordan

speakerInfo.name: JD Jordan
speakerInfo.bio: Author, creative director, UXer, photographer, teacher, and super dad. All in the ATL.

schedule.title: Get Your Node.js API Swaggering with OpenAPI Spec
schedule.description: Let’s explore how using OpenAPI Spec and Swagger tools can make building Node.js APIs even better!
schedule.speaker: Adam Paxton

speakerInfo.name: Adam Paxton
speakerInfo.bio: Builds mobile apps at Polanco Media in sunny South Florida.  Builds realtime location sharing platforms at Condesa.io.

schedule.title: Make Alexa Great Again
schedule.description: Building an Amazon Echo (Alexa) skill is extremely simple, if a bit cumbersome. Skills get the benefit of Amazon's full speech analysis engine and operate through a simple JSON web API. This talk will show how to use Node.js to write a simple skill and what else we need to do to get up and running.
schedule.speaker: Jordan Kasper

speakerInfo.name: Jordan Kasper
speakerInfo.bio: Shortly after it arrived at his home in 1993, Jordan began disassembling his first computer - his mother was not happy. She breathed more easily when he moved from hardware into programming. Jordan's experience includes development and instruction at startups, agencies, Fortune 100 companies, and universities, as well as numerous open source projects. His programming experience includes JavaScript (and Node.js), PHP, Java, Natural, Perl, and more. He speaks regularly at (and helps organize) local user groups and conferences big and small. Jordan's primary mission for over 10 years has been to evangelize technology of all sorts and share what he has learned to help others grow. In his down time he enjoys puzzles of all sorts and board games!

schedule.title: TypeScript for Node.js Development
schedule.description: A desktop engineer that works at Slack recently described his experience with TypeScript as "how he learned to stop worrying and trust the compiler." Companies that switch to TypeScript discover previously hidden bugs, see accelerated delivery, experience reduction of defect rates and increase their trust in code. Learn how to apply these powerful benefits to Node.js development.
schedule.speaker: Jeremy Likness

speakerInfo.name: Jeremy Likness
speakerInfo.bio: Jeremy is a Client Developer Advocate for Azure at Microsoft. Jeremy wrote his first program in 1982, was recognized in the "who's who in Quake" list for programming the first implementation of "Midnight Capture the Flag" in Quake C and has been developing enterprise applications for 20 years. For the past 15 years he has specialized in web-based delivery of line of business applications. Jeremy is the author of four technology books, a six year Microsoft MVP for Windows Platform Development, a Telerik Kendo UI Developer Expert, and speaks and writes regularly on web-based topics such as AngularJS. Jeremy is vegan and spends most of his free time running, hiking and camping with his family, watching retro science fiction movies with his daughter and playing 9-ball and one pocket.

schedule.title: Robust Error Handling in Node.js
schedule.description:
Unlike other platforms, error handling in Node.js is not as simple as try/catch. It can be a handful between exceptions, callbacks, promises, event emitters, and other library patterns.

In this talk, learn to navigate the different error handling mechanisms and build robust Node applications so that when unhandled errors do happen, we can fail gracefully, alert someone, and minimize downtime.
schedule.speaker: Lewis Ellis

speakerInfo.name: Lewis Ellis
speakerInfo.bio: Lewis Ellis is a software engineer working for Sentry, the open source crash reporting and error tracking service. He maintains Sentry's Node.js client which reports 100 million errors every week. Besides contributing to open source, he likes numbers, security, Redis, Lua, and JavaScript trivia.

schedule.title: The fastest way to create a REST API in Node.js
schedule.description: LoopBack is an open-source Node.js API Framework which allows developers to create a REST API in minutes. After a few commands, LoopBack generates much of the code, an API Explorer, and the docs. In this session, we will discuss the underlying concepts behind LoopBack, and walk through the process of creating a simple REST API. Additionally, we will cover Express Gateway, a new open source API Gateway technology.
schedule.speaker: Shikhir Singh

speakerInfo.name: Shikhir Singh
speakerInfo.bio: Shikhir currently works at TeleSign as a Director of Product Innovation. He specializes in JavaScript technologies, enterprise mobility, and cryptography. Prior to joining TeleSign, he worked at Sencha, BlackBerry, Lockheed Martin, Sun Microsystems and a couple of startups.

schedule.title: What The Doc?!?!
schedule.description: Documentation tells the story of your code, application or community and like any great story, effective communication is key.
schedule.speaker: Kim Crayton

speakerInfo.name: Kim Crayton
speakerInfo.bio: Helping To Improve Technical People, Ideas, and Organizations | Tech Speaker | Learner Support Evangelist

schedule.title: React + ASP.NET Core = Awesome!
schedule.description: Learn what you need to add (and remove) to get React running smoothly in your ASP.NET Core MVC application.
schedule.speaker: Lee Brandt

speakerInfo.name: Lee Brandt
speakerInfo.bio: Lee has been writing software for almost two decades in Javascript, C# and Objective-C mostly. He loves to learn new things and then show others what he's learned.

schedule.title: /[Rr]eg(ular\s)?[Ee]x(p$|pression)?/
schedule.description: This talk will help demystify regular expressions: what are they and why should you care? Attendees will get a solid foundation in the core concepts involved. We'll cover character classes, grouping, escaped characters, flags, modifiers, and more!
schedule.speaker: Jordan Kasper

speakerInfo.name: Jordan Kasper
speakerInfo.bio: Shortly after it arrived at his home in 1993, Jordan began disassembling his first computer - his mother was not happy. She breathed more easily when he moved from hardware into programming. Jordan's experience includes development and instruction at startups, agencies, Fortune 100 companies, and universities, as well as numerous open source projects. His programming experience includes JavaScript (and Node.js), PHP, Java, Natural, Perl, and more. He speaks regularly at (and helps organize) local user groups and conferences big and small. Jordan's primary mission for over 10 years has been to evangelize technology of all sorts and share what he has learned to help others grow. In his down time he enjoys puzzles of all sorts and board games!

schedule.title: Develop Hip APIs and Apps with Spring Boot and Angular
schedule.description:
Building a modern web application requires a lot of tools, frameworks and techniques. In this full day workshop, we'll introduce and do hands-on exercises with:
Angular
Spring Boot
Bootstrap

Using Yeoman, a scaffolding tool for modern webapps, JHipster will generate a project that uses Java 8, SQL or NoSQL databases, Spring profiles, Maven or Gradle, Webpack, WebSockets and BrowserSync. It also supports a number of different authentication mechanisms: classic session-based auth, OAuth 2.0, or JWT-based authentication. For production deployments, JHipster includes out-of-the-box support for AWS, Cloud Foundry, Heroku, as well as Docker and Kubernetes.
schedule.speaker: Matt Raible

speakerInfo.name: Matt Raible
speakerInfo.bio: Java Champion and Developer Advocate at Okta with a passion for skiing, mountain biking, VWs, and good . Driving a '66 21-window and a '90 Syncro. Made in Montana. @mraible on Twitter.

schedule.title: Vendor Neutral Serverless Apps in Python/Zappa
schedule.description: Today, no one wants to be responsible for a server.  You want to present a great customer experience and the backend is a necessary evil and you cannot do without.  Here enters “Serverless” with the promise to do provide your backend without servers.
schedule.speaker: Atif Mahmood,Ram Vedam

speakerInfo.name: Atif Mahmood
speakerInfo.bio: Atif Mahmood is a Senior AWS Architect with Anteo Consulting, currently working on Chick-fil-A's cloud initiative.  A full stack architect with 15 years of experience making software products in the desktop, mobile, and cloud space.  He a proponent of Agile software development, Evolutionary Architecture, and building secure software from the ground up.

speakerInfo.name: Ram Vedam
speakerInfo.bio: Polyglot Programmer. Hiking Enthusiast. Philosopher.  Ram Vedam Is a graduate student in Computer Science at Georgia Tech. Ram has a passion for computer science and software development. In his free time, he plays around with many different things to expand his knowledge both in the theoretical and practical applications of technology as well as organizes the Atlanta Functional Programming Meetup. His current interests include web development, Artificial Intelligence, Operating Systems, Programming languages and of course Lisp (All Lisps, from Clojure to CL). He is just your standard regular guy

schedule.title: React Router - what's new?
schedule.description: React Router - what's new?
schedule.speaker: Tim Dorr

speakerInfo.name: Tim Dorr
speakerInfo.bio: Tim is CTO at Showcase IDX. His open source work with React Community (formerly Rackt) focuses on React Router, Redux and webpack-preset. He also reverse-engineered the Tesla Model S API so he can control his car from his watch. Hailing from Atlanta, you may catch him around town DJing your favorite party or biking along the Silver Comet Trail.

schedule.title: Recompose your React.js components embracing a functional style
schedule.description: Too many complicated components slowing your app development down? Recompose is fantastic library which enables simpler more functional React.js components. It is a swiss army knife of component wrappers which eliminate boilerplate and make your code more declarable. Write less code and have more fun.
schedule.speaker: Jeff Barczewski

speakerInfo.name: Jeff Barczewski
speakerInfo.bio: Jeff Barczewski has been a software engineer, architect, and instructor for over 25 years. He is the founder of CodeWinds and Inspired Horizons, a training and consulting firm based in St. Louis, MO. He has taught workshops at conferences such as JazzCon.tech, Strange Loop, JSConf, and Nodevember. He is the author of many open source projects including redux-logic, pkglink, and bench-rest. He is married, father of one, Catholic, who enjoys snow skiing in the Rockies.

schedule.title: Hitchhiker's guide to React
schedule.description: Hitchhiker's guide to React
schedule.speaker: Taggart Bowen-Gaddy

speakerInfo.name: Taggart Bowen-Gaddy
speakerInfo.bio: Taggart is a front end developer passionate about the future of the browser and building powerful web applications.  He is a believer in declarative, functional, human-readable code and abstractions that make our lives as developers easier.

schedule.title: Griddle: a React Datagrid component
schedule.description: Griddle is a composable datagrid for React with support for plugins. In this talk, we'll take a look at Griddle but also cover things such as building a reusable, configurable React component, and architecture decisions that can help a project move quickly over time.
schedule.speaker: Ryan Lanciaux

speakerInfo.name: Ryan Lanciaux
speakerInfo.bio: Ryan Lanciaux is a professional software developer in Ann Arbor, MI. Although he programs in several languages, his current area of focus is front-end development. Ryan attempts to contribute to the development community through his (often neglected) blog.

schedule.title: Add Powerful UI Components to Your React Apps
schedule.description:
React can be used to build user interfaces for web apps, but React developers have to provide the components to build the UI.
In this presentation, you will learn how you can add powerful components to your React apps.
schedule.speaker: Marc Gusmano

schedule.title: JavaScript fundamentals for React
schedule.description: React, demystified: Using plain JavaScript, we examine React's primary abstractions and the patterns commonly found in React applications.
schedule.speaker: Chris Aquino

speakerInfo.name: Chris Aquino
speakerInfo.bio: Chris Aquino is the director of web engineering at Big Nerd Ranch, and co-author of Front-End Web Development: The Big Nerd Ranch Guide. As a developer, he hopes to provide users with meaningful experiences of data. In his current role, he is dedicated to helping his team and his students build a better web. Chris delights in wind-up toys, espresso, and all forms of barbecue.

schedule.title: Strategies for learning React
schedule.description: React has been on your radar for some time but you don't know the best way to dive in to the ecosystem. There are so many awesome libraries but it's hard to distinguish between what's necessary and what's addressing a pain-point you don't yet have.
schedule.speaker: Ryan Lanciaux

speakerInfo.name: Ryan Lanciaux
speakerInfo.bio: Ryan Lanciaux is a professional software developer in Ann Arbor, MI. Although he programs in several languages, his current area of focus is front-end development. Ryan attempts to contribute to the development community through his (often neglected) blog.

schedule.title: Get Started with Redux
schedule.description: Redux is a powerful library for managing application state in an organized manner via a unidirectional data flow. In this talk, learn the benefits of Redux and explore its architecture, including reducers, actions, and middleware.  Also, learn other use cases such as React integration, reducer composition, asynchronous patterns, and testing.
schedule.speaker: Jeremy Fairbank

speakerInfo.name: Jeremy Fairbank
speakerInfo.bio: Jeremy is a web developer with a master's degree in computer science. He has many years of experience in front-end development and full-stack development, working heavily with JavaScript and Ruby. He has presented numerous times at conferences such as Fluent Conf and RailsConf. He is passionate about front-end development and its future, taking that passion to the world of Elm too. He is currently authoring a book on Elm with The Pragmatic Programmers.

schedule.title: The State of State Management in React
schedule.description: These days, managing state in web applications is increasingly difficult. Frameworks like Angular, Ember or Aurelia have some mechanism for managing state built in. But what if you're using React? How do you know which state management solution is right for you? In this session, we'll survey the landscape for managing state in React applications, and walk through some of the more popular solutions, such as Redux and MobX, as well as alternatives like Vue, RxJS and Elm.
schedule.speaker: Jonathan Kemp

speakerInfo.name: Jonathan Kemp
speakerInfo.bio: Jonathan is a Senior Front End Developer at Scripps Networks Interactive working with a team of developers on the websites for their portfolio of popular lifestyle brands including HGTV, DIY Network, and Great American Country.

schedule.title: React and GraphQL with Apollo
schedule.description: Using GraphQL with React is a natural way to get just the data your component needs. With the Apollo Client and React Apollo libraries, we can compose a very easy to use data layer with minimal configuration.
schedule.speaker: Patrick Eisenmann

speakerInfo.name: Patrick Eisenmann
speakerInfo.bio: I'm married, a father of two, and Lead Front-End Software Engineer at Care Logistics in Alpharetta, GA. I've spent the majority of my professional career programming in Javascript starting in 2002, with a few years in PHP, Java, and Clojure.

schedule.title: You don't know Angular
schedule.description: Angular is an incredibly powerful framework with many nuances and quirks. So often as programmers we can create the same mistakes over and over again in our code without ever know there might be a better way.
schedule.speaker: Josh Jensen

speakerInfo.name: Josh Jensen
speakerInfo.bio: Currently a freelance mobile application consultant, Josh brings over 14 years of design, architecture, development and passion to his projects and presentations. In the almost 6 years he has been in the mobile space, he has brought hundreds of applications to market for companies ranging from Fortune 500 to startup, as well as contributing to many open source projects. End to end application structure, including mobile and server application architecture, are just a few of the tools Josh has collected over the years and he is passionate about sharing them with others.

schedule.title: What's coming in Angular 5!
schedule.description: In this interactive session, we'll cover all the cool new stuff and changes in the next version of Angular, which should be released around the time of the conference!
schedule.speaker: Gerard Sans

speakerInfo.name: Gerard Sans
speakerInfo.bio: Community leader. Google Developer Expert

schedule.title: D3 + Angular = Visual Awesomesauce
schedule.description: A picture is worth 1000 words, but a data visualization is worth 1000 table rows. In a world and internet full of data you need to give users value from the numbers. With the combination of D3 and Angular, we can take that data and create versatile and interactive visualizations that respond to dynamic data.
schedule.speaker: John Niedzwiecki

speakerInfo.name: John Niedzwiecki
speakerInfo.bio: John is your friendly neighborhood kilted coder. He has a passion for creating UI, a love of JavaScript-ing all the things, and a drive for both teaching and learning. He's a geeky ginger kilted running dad who codes because he loves it.

schedule.title: ng3000: What is Angular 2 and 4, Why Did They Skip Angular 3, and Why Should I Update from Angular 1.x?
schedule.description: Let's traverse the Angular terrain from the beginning! From discussing the basics of Angular in general, to the big changes from Angular 1.x to Angular 2, to why they skipped Angular 3 and what Angular 4 will bring us - and beyond, we will get a solid understanding of the benefits (okay, and maybe a few drawbacks) of Angular, how to understand their versioning and what exactly it means to us.
schedule.speaker: Whitley Bacon

speakerInfo.name: Whitley Bacon
speakerInfo.bio: Whitley is a Senior Software Engineer at The Home Depot, where she works with Angular, Node, Java, and Pivotal Cloud Foundry. She is a graduate of the University of Notre Dame. She enjoys running, reading, coding, cooking, and spending time with her feisty dog, Sophie.

schedule.title: How do Angular components communicate?
schedule.description: Angular is all about components. In this talk, we will cover the most interesting options available for Angular components to share their data.
schedule.speaker: Alain Chautard

speakerInfo.name: Alain Chautard
speakerInfo.bio: I help web development teams learn and become fluent with Angular. I provide Angular expertise, mentoring and training through code reviews, architecture consulting, bug fixing.

schedule.title: The Journey
schedule.description: The Journey
schedule.speaker: Brandy Porter

speakerInfo.name: Brandy Porter
speakerInfo.bio:
Brandy is the founder and creative director for 9th Path, a user-focused creative services firm. Her career has been spent producing award-winning solutions for top consumer brands like Ford, The Home Depot, and WebM, as well as enterprise solutions for industry verticals including retail, medical, and finance. She has created results-driven interactive experiences on a variety of platforms, devices, and spaces, and also teaches interaction design at corporate and collegiate levels with a focus on user behavior, intuitive design and critical thinking.
 
Additionally, Brandy has built and managed high-performing teams in multiple industry environments, from app dev to advertising. She excels at finding the right mix of people for business and culture, and ensures their success through communication, coaching, and collaboration. She facilitates the sharing of experiential knowledge through FullCircle, a company driven to connect seasoned mentors with individuals experiencing change in their career.

schedule.title: JavaScript Today, Tomorrow, and one Alternative
schedule.description: JavaScript today ES6 features that’s what we are working with. JavaScript tomorrow ES2016/2017 solid features in smaller doses. We now have tools like babel, typescript the alternative to allow us to write language standardized but not officially browser supported yet features. Let's explore the language.
schedule.speaker: Tirell Mckinnon

speakerInfo.name: Tirell Mckinnon
speakerInfo.bio: Tirell Mckinnon is a software engineer at Skookum located in Charlotte, NC.  He is a family man, code writer, avid learner, and a member of the Army National Guard. Frontend development has always been his passion and he has always had a curiosity of deeply understanding software.

schedule.title: Introduction to Functional Reactive Programming
schedule.description: You may have heard of Functional Reactive Program (FRP) via libraries like RxJS. This session will review FRP concepts, explain why it's great for writing asynchronous code, and see some examples in action.
schedule.speaker: Corinna Cohn

speakerInfo.name: Corinna Cohn
speakerInfo.bio: Corinna Cohn has been creating websites since 1995 and has written web apps for radio stations, research projects, scientific publishing, and business-to-business clients. Over the past several years, Corinna has worked with Backbone, Ember, and Angular to design and write single-page applications. Corinna has written ugly, unmaintainable code but is now working to bring the principles of clean code, unit tests, and high-quality refactoring into the realm of JavaScript web application

schedule.title: How I Cut My Working Hours in Half and Somehow Managed to Get More Done
schedule.description: Three hours. In an average eight-hour workday, the average developer will get maybe three hours of actual work done. Between distractions, interruptions, overloaded schedules, and tight deadlines, it can feel like we'll never get anything done. In this talk, Jason Lengstorf shares his story of grinding out 70–90 hours a week, and the surprisingly simple changes he made to turbocharge his productivity, earn more money, and work an average of 37 hours a week in 2016 — while also rediscovering life outside of work.
schedule.speaker: Jason Lengstorf

speakerInfo.name: Jason Lengstorf
speakerInfo.bio: Jason Lengstorf is a developer, designer, author, and friendly bear. He's worked in nearly every role in an agency, from DevOps to sales, and uses his 14+ years of experience to offer a unique, cross-functional approach to solving complex problems. He lives in Austin, TX, spends most of his disposable income on food and travel, and can often be spotted in the forest foraging for nuts and berries.

schedule.title: Escape Callback Hell and enter Callback Heaven with Async Await
schedule.description: JavaScript relies heavily on callbacks for async functions which leads to the infamous 'callback hell'. ES7 is proposing the use of async/await to avoid this. Node.js has already implemented it in version 7.6. I will show you how you can escape from callback hell and reach callback heaven with async await.
schedule.speaker: Jennifer Bland

speakerInfo.name: Jennifer Bland
speakerInfo.bio:
Jennifer Bland is a Senior Software Developer for Hearst Autos, specializing in MEAN stack development. She has more than ten years of development experience working for companies like CNN, Coca-Cola and Apple Computer. Jennifer is the author of the book “Developing e-Business Applications Using Lotus Domino on the AS/400", published by IBM.

She runs the website codeprep.io which provides interview questions to assist programmers in preparation for job interviews. Her personal website is jenniferbland.com.

Jennifer holds a B.A. in History from Furman University and an MBA from San Jose State University.

schedule.title: Energize your development flow with CLIs
schedule.description: Creating personalized CLIs can help you streamline recurring tasks, such as setting up new development environments, managing deployments, and wrangling data. We will walk you through building CLIs in JavaScript to help you avoid costly mistakes and ensure consistent results. Create simple commands that perform powerful tasks.
schedule.speaker: Abraham Williams,Pearl Latteier

speakerInfo.name: Abraham Williams
speakerInfo.bio: An experienced developer, start-up founder, and international speaker, Abraham Williams brings a broad range of skills to his current role as a senior developer at Bendyworks. A top 1% contributor at Stack Overflow and an active member of Google Developer Groups, Abraham has been recognized by Google as a Developer Expert for his ability to identify technology problems and provide quality solutions in the community.

speakerInfo.name: Pearl Latteier
speakerInfo.bio: Pearl Latteier is a software engineer at Bendyworks in Madison WI. She builds JavaScript applications for web and mobile, and she has spoken at conferences around the world on topics including Progressive Web Apps, Web Components, and Polymer. Before becoming a software developer, Pearl earned a PhD in from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, where for five years she taught courses in the Department of Communication Arts.

schedule.title: Afternoon Break
schedule.description: TBD

schedule.title: Finally, Enterprise JavaScript Is Easy!
schedule.description: Oracle JET (oralejet.org) is Oracle's JavaScript toolkit, including data visualizations, architectures, templates, components, and a range of enterprise solutions, such as modularity, internationalization, and accessibility. It is the platform used by Oracle itself for the creation of user interfaces that interact with Oracle Cloud services. It is open sourced on GitHub.
schedule.speaker: Geertjan Wielenga

speakerInfo.name: Geertjan Wielenga
speakerInfo.bio: Geertjan Wielenga is focused on free and open source technologies for enterprise development with JavaScript and Java. He worked for Sun Mircosystems and is currently a product manager at Oracle.

schedule.title: Web Components: Lego bricks of the web
schedule.description: Writing the same login form over and over again? Web components offer a modular approach to creating reusable UI widgets. Use the native web platform to build performant, lightweight building blocks for your site. We will show you how to build custom elements using best practices and how to integrate them with your project.
schedule.speaker: Abraham Williams,Pearl Latteier

speakerInfo.name: Abraham Williams
speakerInfo.bio: An experienced developer, start-up founder, and international speaker, Abraham Williams brings a broad range of skills to his current role as a senior developer at Bendyworks. A top 1% contributor at Stack Overflow and an active member of Google Developer Groups, Abraham has been recognized by Google as a Developer Expert for his ability to identify technology problems and provide quality solutions in the community.

speakerInfo.name: Pearl Latteier
speakerInfo.bio: Pearl Latteier is a software engineer at Bendyworks in Madison WI. For the past several years, she has focused primarily on building data-intensive JavaScript applications for web and mobile, most recently with React JS and React Native. She is also experienced with server-side technologies including Ruby on Rails, Node, and PHP. Before becoming a software developer, Pearl earned a PhD in from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, where for five years she taught courses in the Department of Communication Arts.

schedule.title: Make your animations perform well
schedule.description: Animations have been around the web for some time already; badly implemented can be deadly to the website’s performance and the user’s delight. Let’s learn together what are the best techniques to get our animations smooth and how the browser renders our page to know where to look for optimisations.
schedule.speaker: Anna Migas

speakerInfo.name: Anna Migas
speakerInfo.bio: Anna works as a Front-end Developer and Designer at Lunar Logic, the no-management company based in Kraków, Poland. She is always trying to find ways to make people fall in love with coding and has a long history of organizing coding workshops for WebMuses and Rails Girls. In her spare time she practices Pilates, plays Hearthstone and reads scifi and fantasy books.

schedule.title: An Accessible Guide to Accessibility
schedule.description: ARIA? WCAG? JAWS? Making web apps accessible is often thought of as scary magic. But it doesn't have to be this way. With the right mindset and adherence to a few simple principles, anyone can build accessible web content. Come learn how to make augment your app with semantic helpers for assistive technologies, design with disabled users in mind, and test the way that real users will experience your app.
schedule.speaker: Nick Heiner

speakerInfo.name: Nick Heiner
speakerInfo.bio: Nick is a senior software engineer at the United States Digital Service. Prior to that, he worked at Opower, Google, and Microsoft, and graduated from Cornell. He has contributed to open source projects like Eslint, Bower, Foundation, and Chai. He writes about technology and politics on Medium.

schedule.title: Sense & SVG-ibility
schedule.description: Exploring SVG practices that are so sensible even Jane Austen would appreciate them!
schedule.speaker: Tamil Periasamy

schedule.title: The Decentralized Social Web
schedule.description: We tend to have a love/hate relationship with social networks. The ability to interact with friends, colleagues, and even celebrities is wonderful, but the lack of control over privacy or content algorithms is troubling. A better way lies ahead, where you aren't tied to large social networks and where you can own your own data. Come see a vision for a decentralized Social Web.
schedule.speaker: Keith J Grant

speakerInfo.name: Keith J Grant
speakerInfo.bio: I am a Senior Web Developer at Intercontinental Exchange, where, among other things, I wrote and maintain the CSS for The New York Stock Exchange. I am the author of CSS in Depth.

schedule.title: Secure Network Communications
schedule.description: Some days the Internet feels more like a cage match than a series of peaceful tubes. If you missed Tyler Durden's pep talk, here's your chance to catch up on TLS, cert pinning, and why Mitchell is the malicious attacker.
schedule.speaker: Bolot Kerimbaev

speakerInfo.name: Bolot Kerimbaev
speakerInfo.bio: Android and iOS Sensei at Big Nerd Ranch

schedule.title: Introduction to Kotlin
schedule.description: Kotlin is a new, concise language that is taking the Android development community by storm. We'll talk about why Kotlin is gaining popularity among developers and how you can use it in your Android applications.
schedule.speaker: David Greenhalgh

speakerInfo.name: David Greenhalgh
speakerInfo.bio: David Greenhalgh is an Android Developer and Instructor at Big Nerd Ranch. In his time away from creating top-notch course material, he hones his experience in Kotlin to make way for the future of Android development.

schedule.title: Building Libraries for Kotlin
schedule.description:
Kotlin has a lot of great features that improve developer productivity and make the overall code base more stable. This all works great when you're entire code base is written in Kotlin. However, while Kotlin adoption is growing by leaps and bounds, the fact is that many applications and libraries are still on Java and will be for some time. This means, if you're a library provider like Realm that 100k+ devlopers rely on, you must provide an API that works well for both platforms.
In this talk, you'll learn about some of the challenges faced and approaches taken by Realm to solve this problem and how you might apply these same approaches to your own libraries. You'll also learn about some of the key Kotlin features they used to simplify Realm Mobile Database development with Kotlin.
schedule.speaker: Eric Maxwell

speakerInfo.name: Eric Maxwell
speakerInfo.bio: Eric Maxwell is a Product Engineer at Realm and co-organizer of the Columbus Kotlin User Group. He has spent over a decade architecting and developing software for various companies across many industries. He has developed and taught courses on Java, Android and iOS. When he’s not working, he enjoys time with family, traveling and improv comedy.

schedule.title: Kotlin Coroutines in Android
schedule.description: Kotlin 1.0.1 shipped with support for coroutines. Learn what all the async/await hype is about and practical examples on how to use it in Android.
schedule.speaker: Charles Julian Knight

speakerInfo.name: Charles Julian Knight
speakerInfo.bio: CTO of FIXD Automotive, volunteer organizer with Code for Atlanta

schedule.title: Creating high performance graphics in the browser with WebGL
schedule.description:
During this talk, I will showcase what WebGL is, how it can be used today in any of your web-based projects, regardless of the device you are running it on, and a variety of frameworks to you started.
Prepare to see code, live examples, and high performance computing, including games.
schedule.speaker: Dave Voyles

speakerInfo.name: Dave Voyles
speakerInfo.bio: I am a construction worker turned Technical Evangelist at Microsoft, which is like a developer who talks to developers, and I'm based out of Philadelphia, PA.

schedule.title: No REST for the weary... Introducing GraphQL
schedule.description: RESTful APIs can make fetching data pretty hairy sometimes, but fetching data doesn’t have to be so difficult. Enter GraphQL… the query language where you can ask for exactly what you need with a single HTTP request. Come learn what all the buzz is about!
schedule.speaker: Sia Karamalegos

speakerInfo.name: Sia Karamalegos
speakerInfo.bio: Founder and lead developer for Clio + Calliope Web Development leveraging over 15 years of experience with software engineering to build high-value applications

schedule.title: Using Chrome Developer Tools
schedule.description: Chrome is not just a great browser for viewing websites, but also an invaluable tool for building websites. Out of the box, Chrome ships with "developers tools". Many web developers are aware of this and make use of some of the tools it provides. However, most developers only scratch the surface of what the browser can do.
schedule.speaker: Micah Wood

speakerInfo.name: Micah Wood
speakerInfo.bio: Micah is a full-stack developer specializing in building websites and applications for enterprises using WordPress and React.

schedule.title: Fun with Fabric.js
schedule.description: Have you ever wanted to draw a dynamic chart, run a physics simulation, or create games and animations, all using an HTML5 canvas? Fabric.js makes these projects relatively easy using an object-oriented, easily extendable, open-source library. This introduction walks through creating a simple image editor.
schedule.speaker: K. Devin McIntyre

speakerInfo.name: K. Devin McIntyre
speakerInfo.bio: My strengths as a software engineer include designing code and database architectures, solving memory leaks and performance issues, and the invention of new app features. My current project uses the Angular 1 and Fabric.js frameworks. I specialize in the HTML5 canvas.

schedule.title: Integrating Performance Across the DevOps Lifecycle
schedule.description: In this talk, we will share tips on how to promote performance testing techniques and tools within your organization to ensure performance is addressed early and often in DevOps, instead of the typical afterthought.
schedule.speaker: Amit Patel

schedule.title: Unlocking the power of speech recognition in your app with Titanium+Hyperloop
schedule.description: Gone are all the excuses for why you couldn't add speech recognition into your app!  In this talk, we are going to take an in-depth look at using native speech recognition APIs with the all-new Titanium+Hyperloop.  We'll walk through a live code demo that will give you the simple steps you need to take your cross-platform native apps to the next level.
schedule.speaker: Brenton House

speakerInfo.name: Brenton House
speakerInfo.bio: Brenton House is a Senior Mobile Architect for Shockoe with over 20 years experience in mobile, API, and web development.  He has worked with many clients across various industries including broadcasting, advertising, retail, financial services, transportation, and publishing.  His passion for everything mobile together with his mobile strategy and design experience, drive him to create captivating products that inspire and delight audiences.

schedule.title: Going Web Native
schedule.description: In this talk, we'll take a look at the evolving Web platform and how it's becoming possible to build applications that rival native apps in usability and functionality, while still maintaining the best parts of Web – low friction and simple sharing.
schedule.speaker: Marcus Hellberg

speakerInfo.name: Marcus Hellberg
speakerInfo.bio: Marcus Hellberg is a developer advocate at Vaadin. He works with modern web technologies like Web Components and Progressive Web Applications. His background is in embedded systems but has worked on everything web related for the past 11+ years.

schedule.title: iOS & Android Apps in C# with Xamarin
schedule.description: Building mobile applications for multiple applications can be a handful - different IDEs, languages, and platform APIs. With Xamarin, all of that is converged with Microsoft's .NET framework and Xamarin, an open source C# solution for writing cross platform mobile applications which export native code.
schedule.speaker: Dave Voyles

speakerInfo.name: Dave Voyles
speakerInfo.bio: I am a construction worker turned Technical Evangelist at Microsoft, which is like a developer who talks to developers, and I'm based out of Philadelphia, PA.

schedule.title: An Introduction to Bluetooth Beacons
schedule.description: This is an introductory lecture on what BTLE beacons are and the basics of how they work.  We will look at the two protocols, Apple's iBeacon and Google's Eddystone, and how they differ with each other.  Sample code will be made available to students for download.
schedule.speaker: Anthony A Altieri

speakerInfo.name: Anthony A Altieri
speakerInfo.bio: Anthony is a maker, a nerd, and an IDI.o.T. (Instructional Developer for the Internet of Things).  He regularly speaks at conferences on web development, user analytics, xAPI, and how IoT can be used with online courseware.

schedule.title: Porting an Experience from iOS to Android
schedule.description: In the current iOS-first world, we are often asked to create an Android app based on an existing iOS app. While we often think this process is purely technical, a largely overlooked aspect of the process is ensuring the experience matches the user’s expectations of that platform. In this design-centered session, we’ll be covering mental model differences between iOS and Android, UI components on both platforms, and what to do when when you can’t lean on platform-standard UI in your port.
schedule.speaker: Zack Simon

speakerInfo.name: Zack Simon
speakerInfo.bio: Zack Simon is a UX/UI designer at Big Nerd Ranch, where he conducts user testing and designs web and mobile apps. He works closely with developers to deliver award-winning apps to clients around the globe. In his free time, Zack enjoys designing games and illustrating.

schedule.title: Striking a Balance with UI Tests
schedule.description: It may seem easy to record UI tests, but there are challenges associated with getting them to run consistently. It is difficult to create and maintain a suite of UI tests that grow with your app. We'll explore different approaches to adding UI tests and find a balanced compromise that doesn't bog down a project too much.
schedule.speaker: Jesse Black

speakerInfo.name: Jesse Black
speakerInfo.bio: Jesse Black brings nine years of programming experience to stable|kernel as a software engineer. His passion for programming stems from a love of logic and a need to automate tedious paperwork responsibilities while working for his family’s business. Jesse has a bachelor’s degree in mathematics from New York University. When he's not solving clients needs, he enjoys dusting off old mathematics textbooks, learning Dart and going to see live music.

schedule.title: Crossing the Giant Chasm of Swift
schedule.description: When moving into Swift, it’s easy to become overwhelmed with the weirdness and the shackles. Depending upon which language(s) you’ve used in the past, the post-beginner learning curve for Swift can be daunting. Introductory tutorials aren’t too bad to stomach, but when you want to create anything of value, a giant valley opens up before you. I will show you ways to move past this pain and become a more productive and well-rounded Swift craftsman.
schedule.speaker: Patrick Seda

speakerInfo.name: Patrick Seda
speakerInfo.bio: Patrick is CTO of Colligo Vox, a Mobile solutions consulting company based out of Atlanta. With 30 years of professional experience, he orchestrates and implements successful mobile initiatives ranging from Big Enterprise children’s educational games. Along with his focus of delivering bullet-proof, awesomely kickass solutions, he educates the development community via meetups and the techMatters.fm podcast.

schedule.title: How to Build a View Controller
schedule.description: View Controllers are key to your app, but their role is often misunderstood. Where does their responsibility begin and end? How should they talk to other components? How do you test them? In this talk, you'll learn to apply SOLID principles to design small, composable view controllers that are easy to test.
schedule.speaker: Brian Hardy

speakerInfo.name: Brian Hardy
speakerInfo.bio: A passionate software craftsman, Brian loves to build great mobile apps  to help people get things done. He started working with iOS when it was still called "iPhone OS," and co-authored "Android Programming: The Big Nerd Ranch Guide."

schedule.title: Go to General Mobile
schedule.description: TBD

schedule.title: Go to General Mobile
schedule.description: TBD

schedule.title: UX Design Story for Product Adoption
schedule.description: Without end-user adoption, the best products in the world will fail. Use concepts of story design to adjust your development practices so that product adoption is as much a part of the project as is the code.
schedule.speaker: Katie Stroud

speakerInfo.name: Katie Stroud
speakerInfo.bio: Katie Stroud is the master story crafter for product adoption and corporate culture.

schedule.title: Icons Behaving Badly
schedule.description: The design behind adding interactivity to an application or website seems trivial; download a free icon collection from sites such as Flaticon, Font Awesome, or iconmonstr, pick an appropriate icon, and add the image to your work. However, should there be more to this process, especially if you are concerned about people understanding how to use what you develop? Learn why the "5-second rule" doesn't apply just to picking food off the floor, how the wrong icon can show cultural insensitivity, why the manner icons are placed in a website or app may be as important as the images themselves, and how to perform icon usability tests. You may be surprised which icons users find to be generally instantly recognizable as to what functions they relate, and which others not so much.
schedule.speaker: Andrew Malek

speakerInfo.name: Andrew Malek
speakerInfo.bio: Andrew is a UI developer and designer at NCR, focusing on POS (point-of-sale) and clienteling solutions. He has two decades of development experience in languages such as JavaScript, Visual Basic, Python, and C, and will admit to having developed a content management solution with Delphi and Perl if backed into a corner.

schedule.title: Modern Web APIs for a Better User Experience
schedule.description:
The future of web & mobile-web development is promising with the release of a bunch of new web APIs that will make our lives as developers much easier.

In this talk, we will explore some web APIs that were recently released and see how they can help us build shiny user experiences.
Jad will present the technical side and the pitfalls for every web API, and Nicole will talk about the problems it solves and how it can enhance the user experience for modern web applications.

We will be covering APIs such as online states, intersection observers, cache API and many more.
schedule.speaker: Nicole Saidy,Jad Joubran

speakerInfo.name: Nicole Saidy
speakerInfo.bio: Nicole is a web designer specialized in UI & UX.

speakerInfo.name: Jad Joubran
speakerInfo.bio: Jad is a fullstack teacher and an active conference speaker. He's on a mission to inspire developers around the world by coaching at Le Wagon coding bootcamp in Europe and regularly speaking at international conferences. Lately, Jad's focus lies on spreading knowledge about Progressive Web Apps and mentoring developers through online courses, blog articles and workshops for startups & enterprises. jadjoubran.io

schedule.title: What Big Data is Missing: Remembering Our Humanity
schedule.description: What makes people buy something online? Is it the color of a button, the words in the headline, or eye-catching design? Big data tells us that if we get the right combination of these things, we'll see a huge uptick in sales. But what it doesn't account for is the individual. Because each person that clicks "buy" has a much larger story to tell.
schedule.speaker: Marisa Morby

speakerInfo.name: Marisa Morby
speakerInfo.bio: Marisa Morby has a background in User Experience copywriting, and marketing. She specializes in digital optimization, user research, and user experience flow for web and mobile applications.

schedule.title: When developer must become designer; how to be a one-person UX team
schedule.description:
As a developer with limited resources, experience, and time, how can you embrace your inner UX designer? What is UX and why should you care? Is there really a difference between UX and UI? Which design tools should you use?

In this session I’ll provide you a UX checklist to take you from developer to designer/developer.
schedule.speaker: Angel Banks

speakerInfo.name: Angel Banks
speakerInfo.bio: Angel Banks specializes in UX strategy and design for enterprise, finance, healthcare, and biotech applications. She currently works as a UX designer. Angel has a background in front-end development, project management, product management. Active in the Atlanta tech community, she was a co-organizer of the ATL AngularJS meetup group and is now on the leadership team of Women Who Code Atlanta, co-organizer of ngATL Angular Conference and a UX and Coding Mentor at General Assembly.

schedule.title: Production-Ready Node.js
schedule.description: Node comes with unique engineering requirements - robust node apps tend to handle processes, concurrency, signals, monitoring, and state in similar ways. This presentation explores what it takes to make a Node.js service start fast, stay up, and handle all situations with grace.
schedule.speaker: Hunter Loftis

speakerInfo.name: Hunter Loftis
speakerInfo.bio: JavaScript Junkie and Heroku's Languages team engineering manager.

schedule.title: IoT Prototyping with Node.js and Firebase
schedule.description: In this talk Jen will show you her favorite recipe for prototyping IoT gadgets and blinky LED artwork. It combines Arduinos, Raspberry Pis, NodeBots, and Firebase to yield a forgiving and easy to develop upon IoT platform. Then she'll prove it's quick by building a project on stage, from circuit to code.
schedule.speaker: Jen Tong

speakerInfo.name: Jen Tong
speakerInfo.bio: Jen is a Developer Advocate on Cloud at Google. In this role she helps developers build cool stuff on all sorts of platforms. If she’s away from her laptop, she’s probably skating around a roller derby track, or hanging from aerial silk.

schedule.title: Extending Cloud Intelligence to IoT Devices with Node.js
schedule.description: This session will focus on the tools and resources available around the emerging technology Azure IoT Edge that allows developers to extend cloud intelligence to edge devices with emphasis on Node.js. IoT Edge also enables a gateway that opens up all kinds of scenarios like communicating between devices in real time, operating your IoT solution with an intermittent cloud connection, or enforcing additional security requirements. Whether this is your first time with IoT or you are an expert, this is hot-off-the-press technology and I will do my best to show how to get started and integrate it with existing applications.
schedule.speaker: Kristin Ottofy

speakerInfo.name: Kristin Ottofy
speakerInfo.bio: Kristin is a developer, maker, and mentor with a passion to inspire students, startups, and other developers to build innovative applications using leading edge technology. She specializes in internet of things and web applications and has also worked with many different technologies from chatbots to HoloLens. She has a background in computer science along with math and engineering education. She loves to build open source projects and encourage everyone to create with, think about, and enjoy code. If you tweet her, some LEDs will probably light up!

schedule.title: Blow Your Mind with NPM
schedule.description: Node packages simplify custom reporting to satisfy a customer's real-world need for information. Our team collaborated on cutting down the customer's reporting burden from hours to under a minute! The story of how even beginner Node programmers can have a big impact will blow your mind!
schedule.speaker: Claire Moss

speakerInfo.name: Claire Moss
speakerInfo.bio: Agilist working as part of product development teams to support and accelerate development through fast feedback. I help teams to craft more executable user stories. Strong understanding of needs of product team competencies testing, programming, product ownership, and user experience. Testing teacher, unit and integration test review and advisement, exploratory testing coach. Test automator and exploratory tester. Meetup founder, conference organizer, speaker, workshop facilitator, author, podcaster, and blogger.

schedule.title: Building Real World Node.JS Microservices
schedule.description: “Microservces are small services with independent lifecycles that work together” -Sam Newman. In this talk I'll be presenting some core principles I think represent what makes microservices work well using Node.JS and Docker. After a brief introduction of what microservices are and why they are important, we'll spend the bulk of the time looking at how BDD, CQRS, and Event Sourcing coupled with modern CI/CD techniques can help you deploy containers to a Docker swarm in any cloud. We’ll explore best practices, code, and tooling to get the job done right. I'd say that beginners will get a sense of what microservices are and what makes different, whereas more experienced practitioners will get an insight into practical advice into how to implement them.
schedule.speaker: James Truitt

speakerInfo.name: James Truitt
speakerInfo.bio: James Truitt an agile software developer and technologist. He’s has 17+ years of experience creating software for the TV Broadcasting field. His focus and passion is learning and sharing all things dealing with the cloud. When he’s not behind a computer you’ll find him in the stands cheering on him kids in a local basketball arena.

schedule.title: Get Rails out of your Ruby
schedule.description: We’ll look into what it means to have a framework agnostic architecture in your Ruby app by covering what this means, why you would want it, and strategies to achieve it. Leveraging an architecture that doesn’t depend on Rails will allow the business logic and domain to naturally emerge.
schedule.speaker: Steve Bussey

speakerInfo.name: Steve Bussey
speakerInfo.bio: Coming out of Atlanta, Georgia, Steve is a software engineer and leader looking to help people become more productive. Throughout his time at different SaaS companies, Steve has come to realize the power of software creating a lever to amplify customers' abilities. Steve is at a point where he is looking to increase thought leadership and help others become better along the way.

schedule.title: What the Heck is OAuth and OpenID Connect?
schedule.description: OAuth is not an API or a service: it is an open standard for authorization and any developer can implement it. OAuth is a standard that applications can use to provide client applications with “secure delegated access”. OAuth works over HTTP and authorizes Devices, APIs, Servers and Applications with access tokens rather than credentials, which we will go over in depth below. OpenID Connect (OIDC) is built on top of the OAuth 2.0 protocol. It allows clients to verify the identity of the user and, as well as to obtain their basic profile information. This session covers how OAuth/OIDC works, when to use them, and frameworks/services that simplify authentication.
schedule.speaker: Matt Raible

speakerInfo.name: Matt Raible
speakerInfo.bio: Java Champion and Developer Advocate at Okta with a passion for skiing, mountain biking, VWs, and good . Driving a '66 21-window and a '90 Syncro. Made in Montana. @mraible on Twitter.

schedule.title: Cross-Platform Desktop Apps with Electron
schedule.description: Would you like to leverage your web skills to build cross-platform desktop applications? Electron is an open-source solution designed to make building great desktop applications easy. In this talk, you will learn its features, how to quickly get started, and tips from my experience!
schedule.speaker: David Neal

speakerInfo.name: David Neal
speakerInfo.bio: David is a husband, father of 5 boys, geek, musician, motorcyclist, and Microsoft MVP living in North GA. He's a software developer for LeanKit, and runs on a high-octane mixture of caffeine and bacon.

schedule.title: How to Learn
schedule.description: Software professionals are constantly expected to learn new tricks. It is even more daunting for newcomers to the field, the amount of things you have to learn seems never ending, what's more, everyone tells you something different. This talk will provide some relieve by giving you three principles for learning which will allow you to success in your learning pursuit.
schedule.speaker: Toby Ho

speakerInfo.name: Toby Ho
speakerInfo.bio: Toby Ho is a veteran JavaScript developer in Atlanta. He blogs at tobyho.com and is passionate about helping others learn. He is active in the open source community where his proudest work is Test’em - a Javascript test runner.

schedule.title: Building a Serverless Microservice with AWS
schedule.description: This workshop will demonstrate the basics of how to create Serverless applications and microservices using AWS Lambda, Amazon DynamoDB, Amazon API Gateway, and other serverless services. You will get hands-on experience using standard patterns of creating a small dynamic microservice using Amazon Web Services.
schedule.speaker: Tara Walker

speakerInfo.name: Tara Walker
speakerInfo.bio: Tara is a technical evangelist for Amazon Web Services, dedicating her time to help developers build apps, games, and technical solutions in the AWS cloud. Tara has most recently been working on evangelizing mobile, gaming, IoT, serverless backend architectures, and cross-platform development with AWS.

schedule.title: Lessons from the trenches - Designing Resilient Bulletproof React/Redux Apps Part 1
schedule.description: How do we design resilient apps in this rapid paced modern world? Our apps need to be able to adapt to ever changing requirements and unplanned features. How do we effectively structure our app that it will stand the test of time? How do we apply functional techniques to keep our app simple and easy to reason about?
schedule.speaker: Jeff Barczewski

speakerInfo.name: Jeff Barczewski
speakerInfo.bio: Jeff Barczewski has been a software engineer, architect, and instructor for over 25 years. He is the founder of CodeWinds and Inspired Horizons, a training and consulting firm based in St. Louis, MO. He has taught workshops at conferences such as JazzCon.tech, Strange Loop, JSConf, and Nodevember. He is the author of many open source projects including redux-logic, pkglink, and bench-rest. He is married, father of one, Catholic, who enjoys snow skiing in the Rockies.

schedule.title: Lessons from the trenches - Designing Resilient Bulletproof React/Redux Apps Part 2
schedule.description: Designing resilient apps is difficult. Learn the secrets from the trenches. This session builds on part 1 delving into the more challenging aspects of reactive apps like handling asynchronous I/O, implementing business logic and testing.
schedule.speaker: Jeff Barczewski

speakerInfo.name: Jeff Barczewski
speakerInfo.bio: Jeff Barczewski has been a software engineer, architect, and instructor for over 25 years. He is the founder of CodeWinds and Inspired Horizons, a training and consulting firm based in St. Louis, MO. He has taught workshops at conferences such as JazzCon.tech, Strange Loop, JSConf, and Nodevember. He is the author of many open source projects including redux-logic, pkglink, and bench-rest. He is married, father of one, Catholic, who enjoys snow skiing in the Rockies.

schedule.title: Tame the Async Redux Beast with redux-logic
schedule.description: Keeping our Redux applications tidy can be difficult once we start adding business logic, especially asynchronous code. Where do we write it? How do we write it? And how does our code interact with Redux? Together, we’ll answer these questions and more by exploring how redux-logic lets us “bring our own code” and integrate it in a structured, declarative way with Redux.
schedule.speaker: Ray Gesualdo

speakerInfo.name: Ray Gesualdo
speakerInfo.bio: Ray Gesualdo is a full-stack JavaScript developer, speaker and mentor from Atlanta, GA. He started his career in the e-learning development industry, working with web-adjacent processes and systems before moving into front end engineering. Currently, he leads the front-end and user experience development at 3Blades, a data science-focused startup. Ray loves working with client- and server-side JavaScript; experimenting with serverless architectures and functional programming; and teaching and equipping others in technology.

schedule.title: Lightning Fast React Apps
schedule.description: App loading and run time affect your bottom line. Fancy features aren’t worth if anything users leave the app out of frustration. Every second counts! React is super fast, but you could be shooting yourself in the foot with design decisions. Come learn how to make your React apps lightning fast!
schedule.speaker: Sia Karamalegos

speakerInfo.name: Sia Karamalegos
speakerInfo.bio: Founder and lead developer for Clio + Calliope Web Development leveraging over 15 years of experience with software engineering to build high-value applications

schedule.title: Building Realtime Mobile Apps with React Native and Elixir
schedule.description: Building realtime mobile apps presents several challenges. Most approaches default to complex polling and caching techniques, and/or use subpar toolchains. This talk argues that functional programming is the best way to build scalable mobile apps. The talk demonstrates how to quickly build a realtime  cross-platform mobile app with React Native. In addition, it describes how to use Elixir and the Phoenix framework to drastically reduce the effort and complexity necessary to build a realtime web server. Lastly, the talk argues that this approach is the most maintainable for small to medium-sized development teams.
schedule.speaker: Osa Gaius

speakerInfo.name: Osa Gaius
speakerInfo.bio: Osa Gaius is a Software Engineer at Mailchimp. Previously, he was an engineer at Luma, where he worked on realtime web apps and spread the word about functional programming. In his free time, Osa crafts EDM instrumentals and dances Tango.

schedule.title: Make Your React App Run Smoothly... with TDD Part I
schedule.description:
Have you ever changed some code, and had other code break unexpectedly?
Learn how to reduce  or eliminate those “regressions” and write better code initially, by using test-driven development with your React app. You’ll leave this workshop prepared to write unit, integration, and end-to-end tests for your React app.
schedule.speaker: Van Wilson

speakerInfo.name: Van Wilson
speakerInfo.bio: Van Wilson is a Front-End UI Developer with Cardinal Solutions Group. When he is not testing code, he’s forcing his family to go on long hikes with him.

schedule.title: Make Your React App Run Smoothly... with TDD Part II
schedule.description: Make Your React App Run Smoothly... with TDD PART II
schedule.speaker: Van Wilson

speakerInfo.name: Van Wilson
speakerInfo.bio: Van Wilson is a Front-End UI Developer with Cardinal Solutions Group. When he is not testing code, he’s forcing his family to go on long hikes with him.

schedule.title: Rapid Applications with React Native
schedule.description: Every so often building something is simple. Press button, receive bacon. Life can be simple again. Haven’t we built the same house, or given the same hair cut over and over? 80% of mobile app development is the same old song. So why is mobile so difficult/expensive? It’s not with React Native.
schedule.speaker: Gant Laborde

speakerInfo.name: Gant Laborde
speakerInfo.bio: Inspirational technology strategist.  Tinkerer at heart, but with a passion to ship a quality product at the end.  Love leadership and teaching has driven me to many conferences worldwide.

schedule.title: CSS-in-React with styled-components
schedule.description: CSS in production applications is hard and our industry has worked to mitigate this in multiple ways. Pre/post-processors brought code organization and logic. Class naming conventions helped with specificity. CSS Modules took a big leap forward by providing a certain level of modularity. But CSS never truly matched the level of componentization in its web counterpart, JavaScript...until now. Learn how styled-components leverages React’s component paradigm to provide completely modularized and declarative styling in your React applications.
schedule.speaker: Ray Gesualdo

speakerInfo.name: Ray Gesualdo
speakerInfo.bio: Ray Gesualdo is a full-stack JavaScript developer, speaker and mentor from Atlanta, GA. He started his career in the e-learning development industry, working with web-adjacent processes and systems before moving into front end engineering. Currently, he leads the front-end and user experience development at 3Blades, a data science-focused startup. Ray loves working with client- and server-side JavaScript; experimenting with serverless architectures and functional programming; and teaching and equipping others in technology.

schedule.title: Testing the JavaScript stack with Jest
schedule.description: Testing a modern JavaScript stack can be deceptively complex. Jest provides everything you need to test your entire JavaScript ecosystem, quickly and with simple conventions. In this talk I will, through live coding, demonstrate how to test complex services, data layer, component rendering, and utilities.
schedule.speaker: Clint Ayres

speakerInfo.name: Clint Ayres
speakerInfo.bio: I'm a front end web and native developer for Ventiv here in Atlanta. I've been working with React for since beginning of 2014. I advocate Redux when building at scale with React. I am always looking for new patterns that further separate concerns in React components.  This conference I hope to share all the lessons learned from the past four years and explain how to build high performance and maintainable React applications.

schedule.title: Angular's User Authentication Tool Belt
schedule.description: Your Angular app is nearly done and now you just need to add authentication before it goes out to the real world. Simple, right? Not always. There are a lot of moving parts when it comes to authentication in general and it gets even worse for single page apps. Fortunately for us, Angular provides some great tools that help to make our lives easier when it comes to implementing authentication. In this session you’ll learn about Angular’s user authentication tool belt and how you can get started with it today.
schedule.speaker: Ryan Chenkie

speakerInfo.name: Ryan Chenkie
speakerInfo.bio: Ryan is a full-stack JavaScript developer and works mostly with Angular and Node. He's a Google Developer Expert, Developer Advocate at Auth0, and also runs Angularcasts.io, a screencast site offering end-to-end Angular and JavaScript training.

schedule.title: The best kept secrets of Angular CLI
schedule.description: Angular CLI is a key tool to boost development productivity while working with Angular. While you're probably familiar with its most common features, this talk will unveil some of the best hidden gems of Angular CLI.
schedule.speaker: Alain Chautard

speakerInfo.name: Alain Chautard
speakerInfo.bio: I help web development teams learn and become fluent with Angular. I provide Angular expertise, mentoring and training through code reviews, architecture consulting, bug fixing.

schedule.title: Myths of Angular 2: What Angular Really Is
schedule.description: At ng-Europe in 2014, the Angular team announced Angular 2. Unfortunately, the drastic changes were not well received by many. While things have changed since that announcement during the development of Angular 2, unfortunately many people remember the things said there instead of what was actually done. This session will give an introductory look at the basics of Angular, bust some myths about Angular, and give a look at “why Angular”.
schedule.speaker: John Niedzwiecki

speakerInfo.name: John Niedzwiecki
speakerInfo.bio: John is your friendly neighborhood kilted coder. He has a passion for creating UI, a love of JavaScript-ing all the things, and a drive for both teaching and learning. He's a geeky ginger kilted running dad who codes because he loves it.

schedule.title: Using a Component Library to Create Compelling User Interfaces in Angular
schedule.description: This will be a code-oriented session where we will learn how to utilize a component library for Angular from within a Angular application.
schedule.speaker: Marc Gusmano

schedule.title: Angular Wizardry for AngularJS Folks
schedule.description: Angular 4 (a.k.a. "Angular") is now here with many improvements and optimizations over AngularJS 1.x. In this talk, we will discuss parallels between AngularJS and Angular and how to start a full-functioning web-app using Angular. This is a great way to break into the new library and become an Angular Wizard!
schedule.speaker: Wilson Hobbs

speakerInfo.name: Wilson Hobbs
speakerInfo.bio: Wilson is a mobile web evangelist and Angular developer. He is the founder of Canal, a platform for student life. Wilson is also the developer of a Node framework called Boat, which makes it easy to write REST APIs using Angular-style code.

schedule.title: Machine Learning Guided User Interfaces
schedule.description: Machine Learning Guided User Interfaces
schedule.speaker: Chris Heilmann

speakerInfo.name: Chris Heilmann
speakerInfo.bio: JavaScript veteran from the browser wars. Now working on Microsoft Edge, Visual Studio Code and ChakraCore. AI fanboy, avid presenter and trainer.

schedule.title: Dive into RxJS Observables
schedule.description: RxJS is a library for expressing asynchronous code with Observables. Observables provide a powerful API for handling DOM events, WebSockets, and REST APIs in a unified, composable manner with less code. In this presentation, we will learn how Observables work, the benefits of Observables over Promises, many of the Observable operators, hot versus cold observables, and more. You will leave this talk with a better understanding of RxJS and how to write cleaner, more elegant asynchronous code with Observables.
schedule.speaker: Jeremy Fairbank

speakerInfo.name: Jeremy Fairbank
speakerInfo.bio: Jeremy is a web developer with a master's degree in computer science. He has many years of experience in front-end development and full-stack development, working heavily with JavaScript and Ruby. He has presented numerous times at conferences such as Fluent Conf and RailsConf. He is passionate about front-end development and its future, taking that passion to the world of Elm too. He is currently authoring a book on Elm with The Pragmatic Programmers.

schedule.title: Reactive Programming with RxJS: A Beginner’s Perspective
schedule.description: Why beginners should train yourself to do reactive programming in your first months of learning. As a beginner, you don’t have a set way of programming, and adopting a declarative functional style will help you prepare for the future of reactive programming. Learn the importance of RxJS, simple implementation, and how to think reactively.
schedule.speaker: Tracy Lee

speakerInfo.name: Tracy Lee
speakerInfo.bio: Tracy is the Co-Founder of This Dot Labs, Google Developer Expert, JavaScript developer, and serial entrepreneur. She is also the creator of This.JavaScript, ng-cruise, Modern.Web podcast, RxWorkshop, and Contributor Days. You can find her on Twitter @ladyleet.

schedule.title: Javascript ES6: The Good Parts
schedule.description: Javascript is in the middle of a rapid change. Thanks to new specs and auto-updating browsers, new language features and APIs are at your fingertips. Navigating the bounty of riches is difficult. Which parts should we actually use today, and which are still half baked? What provides real value to your code and which is just syntax sugar.  In this talk I’ll cover the four main features you can actually use today, and how to get them running in your own applications.
schedule.speaker: Josh Marinacci

speakerInfo.name: Josh Marinacci
speakerInfo.bio: Josh is an O’Reilly author, developer advocate, and recovering engineer. He is a senior developer evangelist at Mozilla. Previously he worked as a developer evangelist at PubNub, Nokia, Palm / HP, and Sun. He is passionate about user interfaces and education. Josh lives in sunny Eugene, Oregon.

schedule.title: Stop JavaScripting Like It's 1999
schedule.description: JavaScript is moving fast.  Last year’s best practices are quickly becoming today’s anti-patterns as we experience fundamental shifts in the language. With so many outdated learning resources out there, it's hard to know if we're doing things right.
schedule.speaker: Hunter Loftis

speakerInfo.name: Hunter Loftis
speakerInfo.bio: JavaScript Junkie and Heroku's Languages team engineering manager.

schedule.title: Going Serverless with OpenWhisk
schedule.description: In this talk, I'll introduce the open source serverless framework OpenWhisk. I'll explain what serverless means (to me anyway), why you would use it (and when you would not), and explain how it's implemented in the OpenWhisk environment.
schedule.speaker: Raymond Camden

speakerInfo.name: Raymond Camden
speakerInfo.bio: Raymond Camden is a developer advocate for IBM. His work focuses on LoopBack, serverless, hybrid mobile development, Node.js, HTML5, and web standards in general. He's a published author and presents at conferences and user groups on a variety of topics. Raymond can be reached at his blog (www.raymondcamden.com), @raymondcamden on Twitter, or via email at raymondcamden@gmail.com.
